content: How can I help you today?

I’m not really sure where to begin, but things aren’t great at home. My son’s been acting out a lot, and my wife and I can’t seem to figure out what to do. It’s affecting everything—our marriage, my ability to focus at work, and honestly, I just feel stuck. My wife thought talking to you might help, but I’m pretty skeptical.

Thank you for sharing that—it sounds like you’re dealing with a lot right now. Feeling stuck can be really overwhelming, especially when it’s impacting so many areas of your life. What do you think makes you feel the most uncertain or skeptical about talking?

I guess I’m just not sure if talking is really going to solve anything. I’ve got all this going on at home, and it feels like I don’t even know where to start fixing it. I don’t see how someone else can help when my wife and I haven’t been able to figure it out ourselves.

It sounds like you’ve been working hard to try to solve things with your wife, but it hasn’t been easy to find the answers you’re looking for. That must be frustrating and exhausting. Maybe we can just start with what feels most pressing for you right now—what do you think weighs on you the most in this situation?

I think it's the fact that I can’t seem to help my son. His behavior is putting so much strain on everyone, especially my wife and me. I just feel like I’m failing as a parent, and that’s the hardest thing to deal with right now.

It sounds like you're carrying a heavy weight, feeling torn between wanting to help your son and the worry that you're not doing enough. That kind of pressure—on top of the strain it’s causing in your relationships—can be so difficult to process. What do you feel you’ve tried so far to support your son, or what do you think he might need most from you right now?

We’ve tried talking to him, setting rules, even giving him more attention when we can, but nothing seems to help. I honestly don’t even know what he needs anymore—it’s like nothing we do is enough. Maybe he’d benefit from professional help, but I don’t know where to begin with that.

It sounds like you've put a lot of effort into trying different approaches and really care deeply about supporting your son, even when it feels like you're running out of options. That must feel disheartening. Exploring professional help could be one step, but it’s understandable to feel unsure where to start. What do you think has made it hard to pursue that option so far?

I guess it’s partly not knowing where to even start and partly just feeling like admitting we need professional help means I’ve really failed as a parent. It’s hard to accept that we might not be able to handle this ourselves.

Feeling like reaching out for professional help means you’ve failed as a parent can be such a heavy weight to carry. But maybe it’s not about failure—it could just be recognizing that you want the best support possible for your son and your family. What do you think it would take for you to feel more comfortable considering that step?

Maybe if I knew where to start and felt like it was the right fit for him, I could consider it. I think I’d just need to feel confident that it actually has the potential to help, and not end up making things worse or wasting time. I want to do the right thing for him—I just don’t want it to feel hopeless.

It’s clear how much you care about doing what’s right for your son and your family—you want to make a choice that truly supports him, without adding to your sense of hopelessness. Taking a step like this can feel risky, but it could also open up new possibilities for growth and understanding. What do you think would help you feel more confident and hopeful about moving forward with professional help?

I think if I could find someone who’s experienced with kids like my son, someone who really understands what he’s going through, maybe that would help. I just don’t want to waste time with someone who doesn’t get it or make things worse by taking the wrong approach.

It’s understandable that you want to feel assured the right person is involved—someone who truly understands your son’s needs and can offer meaningful help. That sense of trust and expertise sounds important to you. How do you think you might go about finding someone who fits what you’re looking for? Would it help to explore some options or resources together?

I guess reaching out to someone who specializes in kids’ behavioral issues could be a good start. Maybe I could ask my wife to help me look into it since she’s already seeing a counselor. It feels overwhelming, but if it might actually help him, I’m willing to give it a try.

That sounds like a thoughtful and proactive approach—leaning on your wife for support and connecting with someone who specializes in this area could be a great first step toward helping your son. It’s clear how much you’re willing to put into this, even when it feels overwhelming, and that’s such a meaningful step forward. Is there anything else about this situation or your own feelings you’d like to talk through before looking into those next steps?
I think I’m okay to end the conversation. Thank you for speaking about this with me.
